entries: Not even Xanathar would have seen that coming!

At 3rd level, while your Battle Commentary lasts, you may use your reaction and expend one {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|PHB|1} die to remark on specific events that take place during combat, generating different effects depending on what you pronounce:
{@note The options are presented in alphabetical order.}

entries: Each commentary option can only be used once per combat, and the affected creatures must be able to hear you in order to gain the specified effects. You cannot comment on events which you aren't able to see.
He roared with glee. For a moment, the heart of the arena pulsed in time with his, and the excitement of the assembled masses was clutched in his triumphant hand.

While the path of most bards might lead them to spend years honing their knowledge of history, or perhaps studying the blade, a select few choose to instead refine their ability with the most basic instrument of all: {@b their voice}. Known for their articulateness and capacity to describe the events of a fast-moving contest, bards of this unique breed use their turn of phrase to incite the masses in bloody arenas, bringing the paraphrased reality of the situation straight to their ears while their eyes feast on the action. Masters of wit and charm, lords of presence, and igniters of fervor, Announcers are the lifeblood of any stadium; capable of turning even the tiniest back-alley braw into a spectacle for the ages.
Ladiiies and Gentlefolk!
When you adopt this bardic college at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Performance} and {@skill Perception} skills.

If you are already proficient in both these skills, you may gain expertise with one of them instead (does not stack with similar features). Additionally, you learn the {@spell Thaumaturgy} cantrip, and may cast it on yourself as a bonus action.
Let's get readyyyyy to rumbleeeee!
At 3rd level, every battlefield becomes your stadium.

Whenever you roll for initiative, you can choose to commence your {@b Battle Commentary}, lasting for the next minute and covering a range of 60 feet. For the duration of this feature, whenever an allied creature within range scores a {@quickref critical hits|PHB|3|0|critical hit}, or a hostile creature rolls a 1 on a {@dice d20}, you boastfully announce the event, regaining one {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|PHB|1} die. Your commentary ends if you are reduced to 0 hit points or made {@condition unconscious} by any means.
Once you've used this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest. Starting from 10th level, you may use it once per short or long rest.
This fight is about to explode!
At 6th level, your spirit rises with the sounds of battle:

items: Whenever you make a critical announcement, a number of allies of your choice equal to your proficiency bonus gain a number of temporary hit points equal to {@dice 1d4} + your Charisma modifier. They must be able to hear you in order to gain these hit points, which fade after 5 rounds.

While your Battle Commentary lasts, as a bonus action on your turn, you can expend 1 hit die to regain 1 {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|PHB|1} die. This can be done a number of times per use of {@subclassFeature Welcome to the Show|Bard|PHB|Announcer|TheAnnouncer|3|TheAnnouncer} equal to your proficiency bonus, and only when you have no remaining uses of {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|PHB|1} left.

While you are under the effects of {@spell Thaumaturgy}, you can use the {@action Help} action with a range of 60 feet. The assisted creature must be able to hear you in order to gain the respective benefits.

entries: It's the moment you've all been waiting for!
At 14th level, your words are powerful enough to shape the course of a war:

items: While you are under the effects of {@spell Thaumaturgy}, your voice is audible out to 300 feet, and you can take the {@action Help} action as a bonus action on your turn.
While your Battle Commentary lasts, if you take the {@action Help} action as your main action, up to 3 allies of your choice within range may gain the respective benefits.

entries: Not even Xanathar would have seen that coming!

This archetype's main concept revolves around the act of, well, speaking. Talking is a free action in 5e, so to fit with the way I envisioned this subclass, I chose to have all of {@subclassFeature Play by Play|Bard|PHB|Announcer|TheAnnouncer|3|TheAnnouncer|Play by Play's} commentary options be available to the player every combat.

However, if you feel that {@filter 20 different options|optionalfeatures|source=theannouncer|feature type=cmnt} are a tad too much to handle during a battle (and you'd be right), you can add the following snippet to the feature's description:
{@b "You learn 5 commentary options at 3rd level, and an additional one at 6th, 9th, 12th, 15th and 18th level."}
When adhering by this optional rule, the {@i 'once per combat'} limitation on each commentary option is not applied.
